Introduction

Domestic violence and abuse affects 1 in 4 women and 1 in 6 men during their lifetime. Anyone can be a victim of domestic abuse regardless of their age, gender or sexuality. All individuals at risk of or experiencing domestic abuse are equally deserving of respect and support from our staff. There are some 2.3 million victims of domestic abuse a year aged 16 to 74 (two-thirds of whom are women) and more than one in ten of all offences recorded by the police are domestic abuse related (DOH 2021).

Domestic abuse is any incident, or pattern of incidents, of threatening, controlling, coercive behaviour, violence or abuse, between those aged 16 or over who are, or have been, intimate partners or family members regardless of gender or sexuality.
The abuse can include, but is not limited to:
Psychological
Physical
Sexual
Financial
Emotional

Domestic abuse can occur in any form of relationship, including intimate partners or family members (current or ex-partners), cohabitants, persons who live or have lived in the same household, mother, father, son, daughter, brother, sister, and grandparents, whether directly related, or in-laws or step family.

Domestic abuse can also include aspects of harm or abuse that affect mainly women from minority ethnic backgrounds such as forced marriage, female genital mutilation, and abuse and violence in the name of honour (also called ‘honour'- based violence).

Research findings indicate that many survivors of domestic abuse wanted someone to ask them or enquire what was happening at home when they came in contact with health professionals. The NHS therefore has a particular contribution to make in supporting service users who are suffering domestic violence and abuse. The Royal College of Midwives also states that every midwife plays a role in the detection and management of domestic abuse.
NHS Trusts have a statutory duty to work with the Crime and Disorder Reduction Partnerships to reduce local crime including domestic abuse (Crime and Disorder Act 1998).

Mid & South Essex NHS Foundation Trust is committed to providing services on a basis of equality, diversity and freedom from unlawful discrimination. This commitment applies to all individuals at risk of or experiencing domestic abuse. Unlawful discrimination is that related to:

Scope
The purpose of this document is to:
Provide guiding principles for staff to identify and support individuals who are experiencing or at risk of domestic abuse.
Promote the safety of the individual at risk of, or experiencing domestic abuse.
Promote and protect the welfare of children and the unborn infant.
Promote the safeguarding of adults at risk of abuse or neglect.
Provide information on available resources to anyone experiencing or at risk of domestic abuse.
Promote interagency working and participation with MARAC (Multi Agency Risk Assessment Conference) and internal and external domestic abuse services
Communicate and promote the domestic abuse support available within the Trust and the local community.

Individuals at risk of or are experiencing domestic abuse are at risk of increased abuse when an individual begins the process of disclosure, seek help or when they attempt to leave an abusive relationship. It is therefore important that those disclosing abuse feel safe and that the sensitivity of the situation is understood and considered.

This policy is aimed at all staff within Mid & South Essex NHS Foundation Trust (MSE) who are involved in the care of adults, children and young people and their families who are at risk of or are experiencing domestic abuse.

Definitions

table_items.text: Domestic Abuse / Violence (Updated with reference to Domestic Abuse Act 2021)

Domestic Abuse Act 2021: Behaviour of a person (abuser) towards another person (abused) is “domestic abuse” if (a) Abuser and abused are each aged 16 or over and are personally connected to each other, and (b)the behaviour is abusive. Behaviour is “abusive” if it consists of any of the following— (a)physical or sexual abuse; (b)violent or threatening behaviour; (c)controlling or coercive behaviour; (d)economic abuse ; (e)psychological, emotional or other abuse; and it does not matter whether the behaviour consists of a single incident or a course of conduct. (5)For the purposes of the Act abusers behaviour may be behaviour “towards” the abused despite the fact that it consists of conduct directed at another person (for example, the abused's child). Domestic Abuse Act 2021 (legislation.gov.uk)
Children affected by domestic abuse Violence (Updated with reference to Domestic Abuse Act 2021)

The Act states that a child who sees or hears, or experiences the effects of, domestic abuse and is related to the person being abused or the perpetrator is also to be regarded as a victim of domestic abuse. This will put a statutory duty on locally commissioned services to consider and address the needs of children affected by domestic abuse.

The Act defines people who are ‘personally connected' as: intimate partners, ex-partners, family members or individuals who share parental responsibility for a child. There is no requirement for the victim and perpetrator to live in the same household.
Includes intimidation and threats, social isolation, verbal abuse, humiliation, constant criticism and enforced trivial routines.
Includes slapping, pushing, kicking, stabbing, damage to property or items of sentimental value, attempted murder and murder.
Includes controlling who the victim sees or where they go, what they wear or do, stalking, imprisonment and forced marriage.

data.text: violence & abuse/MSEPO-21116/1.0

table_items.text: Includes any non-consensual sexual activity, rape, sexual assault, coercive sexual activity or refusing safer sex.

“Economic abuse” means any behaviour that has a substantial adverse effect on a victims ability to — (a)acquire, use or maintain money or other property, or (b)obtain goods or services. Domestic Abuse Act 2021 (legislation.gov.uk)
Includes stealing, depriving or taking control of money, running up debts, withholding benefit books or bank cards
Any person aged 18 years or over. Although domestic abuse guidance refers to individuals of 16 years of age

A person under the age of 18. Harm of a child under the Children's Act 1989 means ill- treatment or the impairment of health or development including, for example, impairment suffered from seeing or hearing the ill- treatment of another.

Child Protection is a term used to describe the activity that is undertaken to protect specific children who are suffering or likely to suffer significant harm. It is underpinned by legislation and Statutory Guidance
Asking people directly about their experiences if any, of domestic abuse where there are concerns or suspicions, including the presence of signs and symptoms that domestic abuse may have occurred.
Routine Enquiry in Midwifery Ante Natal Services

Asking all women who are using the service direct questions about their experiences, if any, of domestic abuse regardless of whether there are signs of abuse or whether abuse is suspected. This is usually performed at first antenatal appointment with the midwife.

Domestic homicide review means a statutory review of the circumstances in which the death of a person aged 16 or over has, or appears to have, resulted from violence, abuse or neglect by (a) a person to whom he or she was related or with whom he or she was or had been in an intimate personal relationship; or (b) a member of the same household as himself / herself with a view to identifying the lessons to be learnt from the death. Domestic Homicide Reviews (DHRs) were established on a statutory basis under section 9 of the Domestic Violence, Crime and Victims Act (2004).

If an individual has mental capacity, they are able to make specific decisions for themselves. The legal definition says someone who lacks capacity cannot do one or more of the following four things: Understand information given to them Retain that information long enough to be able to make a decision

Multi Agency Risk Assessment Conference The main aim of the MARAC is to reduce the risk of serious harm or homicide for a domestic abuse victim assessed to be at the highest risk of domestic homicide and to increase the safety, health and wellbeing of other victims, both adults and children. In a MARAC local agencies will meet to discuss the highest risk victims of domestic abuse in their area. Information about the risks faced by those victims, the actions needed to ensure safety, and the resources available locally are shared and used to create a risk management plan involving all agencies.
Southend Essex and Thurrock Safeguarding Adults Form
Standardised checklist that enables professionals who are working with the victims of domestic abuse identify those who may be at high risk of serious harm or homicide.

Recognising domestic abuse

Health Practitioners are in a key position to identify domestic abuse and to initiate support and safety for victims. A study of 2500 women accessing domestic abuse services, showed that prior to receiving specialist help, just under half had attended a GP and average of 5.3 times and one in five had attended A&E as a result of abuse.
Responding to domestic abuse – A Resource for Health Professionals (2017)
Staff should never assume that someone else will take care of domestic abuse issues and disclosures as that staff member may be the individuals first and only contact.
RADARR is a useful mnemonic for staff to assist in the management of domestic abuse disclosure:
R Routinely screen patients
A Ask Questions
D Document Findings Safely
A Assess Patients Safety
R Resources: give patients information on resources available and R Respect their choices.

There are a number of indicators of domestic abuse, which staff must be aware of. These are not absolute evidence that abuse has definitely occurred and is not exhaustive, but all staff members need to recognise the physical, emotional and behavioural indicators that raise suspicions that a patient may be experiencing or at risk of domestic abuse and may require support (Appendix 1)
Staff members must make appropriate assessments of all individuals attending for health care using the indicators within Appendix 1.
Policy for the management of individuals / service users at risk of or experiencing domestic violence & abuse/MSEPO-21116/1.0
It is the responsibility of all staff to know about internal and external local domestic abuse pathways and be confident that they know how and when to seek advice (Appendix 5).
All staff must be aware that to tackle domestic abuse, it is essential that victims are identified and disclose their abuse as early as possible.
Asking about domestic abuse – principles of conduct

Health professionals are often a first point of contact for an individual at risk of or experiencing domestic abuse. All staff have a responsibility to know and recognise the signs of domestic abuse, facilitate disclosure in private without any third parties present, to be attentive and use further questioning skills that enable the staff member to assess the risk and need for further intervention.

It is important that during this contact the staff member considers that an intervention could make the individual and/or the individual's children safer, but could also, if not handled correctly, cause further risk of danger. It is therefore important that staff apply safe principles and always seek advice if required.

Individuals at risk of or experiencing domestic abuse can feel ashamed, humiliated and frightened and may blame themselves for their situation. Therefore, when asking someone about domestic abuse, it is important that this is done in a sympathetic manner and in an environment in which the individual can feel safe.
General principles to follow include:

Ensure that the safety of the victim (and of any dependent children or adults with care or support needs) is the paramount consideration. Note that under the Domestic Abuse Act 2021, children are now considered victims if witnessing domestic abuse (see definitions).
Treat people with respect and dignity at all times; listen to what they are saying and do not be judgemental; establish empathy and trust.
Seek to empower people to make informed decisions and choices about their lives, and do not try to make decisions on their behalf.

Respect the individual's confidentiality and privacy, and recognise the real dangers which may be created if this is or is not breached and manage accordingly Note that any safeguarding concern or abuse of children, young people or unborn including domestic abuse incidents must be referred as per child safeguarding procedures.
Recognise the skills and contributions which other agencies are able to make, and co-operate with them.
Ensure that you do not place yourself or colleagues at risk in a potentially violent situation.
Policy for the management of individuals / service users at risk of or experiencing domestic violence & abuse/MSEPO-21116/1.0

Signpost / refer to Domestic Abuse Support Services, including for the Essex area, Compass (Essex) Domestic Abuse Helpline: 0330 333 7 444. Refer to Appendix 5 for area specific and national support services.
It is important when enquiring about domestic abuse that the location is secure and confidential and that the individual is alone (see Appendix 1 and

2). If the individual does not speak English a relative should not be used as an interpreter; a Trust approved interpretation service must be used. The enquiry should be put in a sensitive way and should facilitate open discussion. Documentation of the outcome of any enquiry and action taken should be made.
Guidance for staff on asking about domestic violence can be found in Appendix 2.
Documentation and information sharing

Care must be taken when documenting domestic abuse. In order to maintain confidentiality and maintain the safety of the individual and their children, any record of domestic abuse should be in a record that can only be accessed by those directly involved in the victims care and not in written notes which may be held by the patient or which the perpetrator could have access to. Permission is not required to record a disclosure of domestic abuse or the findings of an examination. However staff must make it clear to the individual that, as a duty of care, they have a responsibility to keep a record of the individuals' disclosure and injuries.
When making a record staff should include:
Exactly what happened.
Use patients own words (with quotation marks) rather than the words of the staff member.
Document injuries in as much detail as possible, using body maps.
Use photography where possible, but only by the Trust Medical Photography Service or approved devices as per Trust Policies.

If using computerised records, ensure that nothing about domestic abuse is viable on the opening screen. All individuals at risk or, or experiencing domestic violence should be flagged accordingly on hospital IT systems to notify staff that individual is known to safeguarding services. Staff should be familiar with and refer to the ‘MSE Acceptable Use of IT Systems Policies'.
Policy for the management of individuals / service users at risk of or experiencing domestic violence & abuse/MSEPO-21116/1.0

In some instances, failure to share information correctly can put victims at risk. When sharing information about patients, breaking confidentiality has to be based on consent, unless there is a public interest or other legal justification. Staff should be familiar with and refer to when required the guidance: Confidentiality: NHS Code of Practice (2003).

Consent should always be sought from the individual at risk, before sharing information. However, the Crime and Disorder Act 1988 states that it is permissible to pass Information to another agency in situations where:
The Courts request information about a specific case or
If there is significant risk of harm to the person, their children or somebody else if the information is not passed on.
If information is shared without permission health professionals must ensure that this decision does not place somebody at greater risk.
It is best practice, where possible and safe, to ensure the individual is kept informed of any referrals or actions taken.
Identification, risk assessment and referral

A DASH is the local risk assessment tool to be used to gather information from an individual at risk. When completing a DASH (Appendix 4) it must also be considered if an Adult Safeguarding Referral is needed and a Safeguarding Children's referral must be made if there are children within the family / home.

Prior to completing the DASH, staff must ensure that they discuss with the individual and seek their permission about possible referral to MARAC. In cases of very high risk, information can be legally disclosed even if the individual has not given consent. In this case, the staff member should seek advice from a safeguarding professional.
Staff should complete the DASH and forward the original copy of the DASH to the Adult Safeguarding Team on their local site.

If the DASH score is high (14 or over) then a MARAC referral must also be made. The score of 14 is a guide for MARAC referral. A referral to MARAC can be made on professional judgement and stating rationale for high risk decision if the risk assessment score is below 14.
Policy for the management of individuals / service users at risk of or experiencing domestic violence & abuse/MSEPO-21116/1.0
The assessment and referral process is:
Identification
Completion of a DASH Risk Assessment by staff or member or service
Assess need for referral to MARAC for DASH Score of 14 and above, or on professional judgement. Also consider referral to Adult Social Care under Safeguarding Adults Procedures.
Refer to Local IDVA (Independent Domestic Violence Advocacy services) and / or specialist violence services (Appendix 5).
Refer to children's social care of there a children within the family network.
Contribute to multi agency assessment.
Provide safety interventions as necessary.
Guidance for midwifery services

Any disclosure of domestic abuse in antenatal screening during routine enquiry will be recorded on the DASH form and uploaded onto electric patient records that can be accessed via the acute care portal. Midwives should seek support completing the DASH where appropriate from safeguarding services.

An initial enquiry regarding domestic abuse should be made at booking if possible by the Community Midwife, then at least twice more at any contact either in hospital or community. The ‘Routine Enquiry' column in the hand held records should then be signed to indicate that the question has been asked successfully.

It is important when enquiring about domestic abuse that the location is secure and confidential and that the woman is alone (see Appendix 1 and 2). If the individual does not speak English a relative should not be used as an interpreter; a Trust approved interpretation service must be used. The enquiry should be put in a sensitive way and should facilitate open discussion. Documentation of the outcome of any enquiry and action taken should be made.

MSE has additional information for pregnant women on the hospital website relating to safety in pregnancy which covers domestic abuse. Additionally the new hand held records has a bar code which denotes the number of the national domestic abuse helpline.

No other information relating to domestic abuse will be recorded in the hand held maternity record. Identify health partners who will be working with the individual – i.e Health Visitor and GP to share information in the best interest of the individual and to safeguard the unborn.

The importance of documented information about domestic abuse should be explained; records can provide concrete evidence of abuse and may prove to be crucial in influencing the outcome of any legal case.
Policy for the management of individuals / service users at risk of or experiencing domestic violence & abuse/MSEPO-21116/1.0
Assessment / DASH risk identification outcomes

Individuals at risk of or experiencing domestic abuse who have been identified during selective or routine enquiry and assessment should have a DASH Risk Identification Checklist completed (Appendix 4). The DASH will direct the staff member to ask questions relevant to domestic abuse so that a risk assessment can be informed. The DASH should be completed by staff that have knowledge of the individual and can talk sensitively and competently through the questions on the risk assessment with the individual. Where the staff member is not able to complete the DASH this must be recorded and referred to the line manager for advice.

A total of  or more is the suggested threshold for referral to MARAC (Multi Agency Risk Assessment Conference). However, if the staff member believes an individual is at high risk, but does not score 14 or more, then the referral can be made to MARAC on professional judgement. In this case the staff member must indicate their professional opinion in the designated space to explain the rationale for this decision. Staff should seek advice from a safeguarding professional if required.

The completed DASH must be forwarded to the Site Adult Safeguarding Teams for review before referral to MARAC. For low to medium risk cases that do not score 14 or above, and are not MARAC referred on professional judgment, the staff member should consult with safeguarding services to identify what other support may be appropriate for the individual. A list of support services can be located in Appendix

The staff member completing the DASH risk assessment should notify the individual if the MARAC referral criterion has been met; advise the individual of the purpose of MARAC and discuss what outcome(s) the individual would like as a result of the referral. If this is not done, then the referral may be declined and support services may not be able to contact the individual at risk.

Referrals to MARAC do not necessarily require the individuals consent, particularly in high risk cases. However, it is good practice to discuss the referral with them. The staff member should seek advice from a safeguarding professional if a high risk individual declines a referral.
Responding to disclosures

Staff members must approach a disclosure with empathy, taking into consideration that it may have taken significant time and courage to disclose the abuse. It is important that a supportive and safe environment is created to promote disclosure and engagement.

The approach of the staff member may determine whether the individual chooses to continue to disclose and seek help, or whether they make the decision to withdraw from support - The fear of not being believed, or of being blamed for what has happened, may stop someone from talking about their experience of violence.
Policy for the management of individuals / service users at risk of or experiencing domestic violence & abuse/MSEPO-21116/1.0

When a disclosure has been made, it is essential that the response of the staff member is sympathetic, supportive and non-judgemental. Refer to section 7 of this policy for guidance on information sharing and situations when a confidence may need to be breeched. Always seek advice if needed.
Safety planning

To ensure the safety of individuals at risk, security may need to be involved for high risk cases on site and informed of potential perpetrators to support with restricting visiting or support where needed on the ward.

Incorrect advice could put the individual at further risk. It is important to consider safety advice and ensure the individual is involved in any safety planning and directed to sources of specialist advice. See Appendix 5 for support services

The staff member should discuss with the individual where he/she can go for help, and how to contact local services including the Police Domestic Abuse and Safeguarding Unit; SOS Domestic Abuse Project; Rape Crisis etc. (see Appendix
5). Signpost / refer to Domestic Abuse Support Services, including for the Essex area, Compass (Essex) Domestic Abuse Helpline: 0330 333 7 444.

The nature and type of help should be in direct response to the individuals identified needs and preferences. Personalisation in safeguarding requires engaging with the individual at risk to understand the outcome they want to achieve from seeking help, and supporting to achieve the identified outcomes. It should be recognised that the requirements of the individual may change so staff should be sensitive to this. Staff should consult with the individual before taking a decision on any intervention and should also take account of their wishes and best interest.
Staff should consider any help required by the individual to make contact with other agencies, and should give this assistance where possible.
A child protection referral should always be completed within the safety plan if there are children or pregnant women (victim or perpetrator) within the household or witnessing the domestic abuse.

It is the responsibility of the staff member to ensure that the individual at risk is safe to be discharged and has a place of safety to be discharged to. It is also the responsibility of the staff member to ensure a safe telephone number and safe contact time is established so that the individual can be contacted safely by support services after discharge. The individual must always be advised to phone 999 for immediate assistance in an emergency.

The Silent Solution system enables a 999 mobile caller who is too scared to make a noise or speak, to press 55 when prompted – to inform police they are in a genuine emergency. The system is well established in the UK. Police will not automatically attend to a silent caller. Callers need to listen and respond to questions and instructions. It is important for the victim to try and provide as much information as they can during the call – in any way they can. A victim can respond in many ways, including by coughing or tapping the handset if possible, or if using a
Policy for the management of individuals / service users at risk of or experiencing domestic violence & abuse/MSEPO-21116/1.0

mobile phone, once prompted by the automated Silent Solution system, pressing 55. If a victim is unable to listen to the instructions given by the system, they should continually tap the handset or continually press 55 to help the system recognise the call as an emergency.
Mental capacity and safeguarding adults

It is presumed that an individual has mental capacity to make informed choices about their own safety and how they live their lives unless proven otherwise by a decision specific mental capacity assessment. Issues of mental capacity and the ability to give informed consent are central to decisions and actions in the safeguarding individuals at risk. All interventions need to take into account the ability of individuals to make informed choices about the way they want to live and the risks they are prepared to take in the context of their own lives:
This includes their ability to understand the implications of their situation
To take action themselves to prevent abuse
To participate to the fullest extent possible in decision making about interventions.

For further information regarding assessing mental capacity, refer to Mental Capacity Assessment Policies or if assessment of mental capacity of a young person is required then refer to Gillick competency and Fraser Guidelines.
For further guidance on mental capacity, staff should refer to the ‘MSE Policy for Mental Capacity Act 2005'.
Ill treatment and wilful neglect

An allegation of abuse or neglect of an adult at risk who does not have capacity to consent on issues about their own safety should always be considered for referral under the Safeguarding Adults Procedure. Subsequent decisions must be made in the individual's best interest using a best interest process.

Appendix 1: Recognising possible signs/symptoms of domestic abuse
Inconsistent relationship with health services
frequent appointments for vague symptoms
frequently missed appointments, including at antenatal clinics
non-compliance with treatment or early discharge from hospital Physical symptoms
injuries inconsistent with explanation of cause or the woman tries to hide or minimise the extent of injuries
multiple injuries at different stages of healing or repeated injury, all with vague or implausible explanations (particularly injuries to the breasts or abdomen)
problems with the central nervous system – headaches, cognitive problems, hearing loss
unexplained:
– long-term gastrointestinal symptoms
– genitourinary symptoms, including frequent bladder or kidney infections
– long-term pain
Reproductive/sexual health issues
unexplained reproductive symptoms, including pelvic pain and sexual dysfunction
adverse reproductive outcomes, including multiple unintended pregnancies or terminations/miscarriages
delayed antenatal care, history of premature labours or stillbirths
vaginal bleeding, recurring sexually transmitted infections or recurring urinary tract infections
Emotional or psychological symptoms
symptoms of depression, fear, anxiety, post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), sleep disorders
self-harming or suicidal tendencies
alcohol or drug misuse
Intrusive ‘other person' in consultations

partner or spouse, parent, grandparent (or, for elder abuse, a partner or family member) always attends appointments unnecessarily

the patient is submissive or afraid to speak in front of the partner or relative, escort or spouse. The escort is aggressive, dominant or over attentive, talking for the patient or refusing to leave the room.

None of these signs automatically indicates domestic abuse, but even if the patient chooses not to disclose at this time, knowing that you are aware of the issues and are supportive builds trust and lays the foundations for them to choose to approach you or another practitioner at a later time.
Young women

Young women can have additional signs such as indicators of sexual exploitation (see the Health Working Group Report on Child Sexual Exploitation, Annex C, page 77)49, going missing and gang involvement.

Appendix 2: Asking about domestic abuse – Good Practice Guide
Asking about domestic abuse – Good Practice

Only question the victim about domestic abuse when you are alone with the individual in private. Never question a suspected victim of domestic violence in the presence of others as that person could be related to the abuser or be the abuser.
Ensure privacy

The consultation should take place in a space in which confidentiality can be assured and where the patient cannot be overheard or seen from the outside and where there will not be a disturbance or interruption of the interview.
Ask direct questions
Explain you are concerned. If it is a routine enquiry, explain that you ask everyone. Direct questions should be asked respectfully but may include:
Has anyone ever hit you? Who was it? What happened? When? What help did you seek?
Are you ever afraid at home or in your relationship? Have you been pressured or made to do anything sexually that you did not want to do?
Are you safe at home?
Are you being looked after properly/is your partner taking care of you?
Do you get on well with your partner?
Consideration when contact with children
Talk sensitively and directly to each child.

There are children who do not want to talk and others who disclose indirectly, and will require prompting. They may disclose in a roundabout way. The child may be hoping that you will take up the hint they are offering.
Don't interrogate the child. Ask simple questions such as:
Is there something you're sad or worried about?
Use reassuring phrases such as:
I believe you
I am glad you came to me
I am sorry that this has happened
You're not to blame
We are going to do something to get help
Consider the need for an interpreter or advocate
Policy for the management of individuals / service users at risk of or experiencing domestic violence & abuse/MSEPO-21116/1.0

Some people may need another professional to be present (same gender) either as an interpreter (for different languages or sign languages) or as an advocate (particularly if the person has a learning disability) or for moral support. The person who is used as an interpreter should be independent, a professional interpreter and have received domestic abuse training. It is not acceptable to use family members or friends, or to use staff who have not been trained as interpreters.
Emphasise confidentiality
But be clear about its limits and explain these to the patient, for example if there are reasons to believe an adult or child may be at risk then information may have to be shared.

Risk Identification for Trained Front Line Practitioners (Please refer to the DASH (2009) Practice Guidance on Risk Identification in full)

A number of high risk factors have been identified as being associated with serous violence and murder through researching many cases. Any professional using the DASH (2009) must be trained in it's use. This is crucial to understanding what the high risk factors are and how they apply in each situation, and what needs to be done to keep the victim safe.

This form should be completed for ALL cases of domestic abuse by front line staff. Initial risk identification must be undertaken by asking ALL the questions on this checklist, as well as searching appropriate databases, such as the intelligence databases. First response staff and their supervisor should identify risk factors, who is at risk and decide what level of intervention is required.

Details of children resident at the address must be provided. Consider the nature of the information and what it means in terms of public protection - preservation of life, reduction and prevention of harm to victim and others.

Please ensure that when you ask these questions the victim is comfortable and understands why you are asking them – it is about their safety and protection. Particular sensitivity and attention is required when asking about whether the victim has been assaulted, physically and/or sexually by the perpetrator. The vulnerability of victims cannot be overstated. This could be further compounded by issues such as traditional gender roles, literacy, language and/or immigration or refugee status. Please take into consideration the victim's perception of risk.

Please ensure you ask the victim about the abuser's behaviour when stalking and honour based violence are present. Do not just tick the box ‘yes'. You must identify what is happening. There are specific risk factors that relate to these areas as well. Assessment of risk is complex and NOT related to the number of risks appearing alone. Rather, the risk posed to the victim or others in a particular situation will be dependent upon what they are and how they apply in that context. Refer to the full DASH (2009) Practice Guidance on Risk Identification.
Record what steps you have taken to ensure the immediate safety of the victim(s) and any children. Ask yourself ‘Am I satisfied that I have done all I can?'  Everything you do must be recorded.

The risk identification process must remain dynamic. Events and circumstances may undergo rapid and frequent change. Where this is the case, the assessment must be kept under review. Risk identification is based on structured professional judgement. This model is most effective when undertaken by professionals who have been fully trained in its use. High risk cases may well require a multi-agency response and should be referred to the relevant risk management panel i.e. the Multi-Agency Risk Assessment Conference (MARAC) or Multi- Agency Public Protection Panel (MAPPP). MARACs are for the most serious and high risk cases.

Risk Assessment CategorisationThis is based on the Offender Assessment System (OASys) developed by the Prison and Probation Services definitions of what constitutes standard, medium, high risk. Please use your professional judgement to categorise the risk level:

table_items.text: Current evidence does not indicate likelihood of causing serious harm.

There are identifiable indicators of risk of serious harm. The offender has the potential to cause serious harm but is unlikely to do so unless there is a change in circumstances, for example, failure to take medication, loss of accommodation, relationship breakdown, drug or alcohol misuse.

Appendix 5: Domestic Abuse Support Services

Silent Solution

If you are in an abusive household and need the Police but fear being heard, Dial 999, Listen to the questions from the 999 operator, respond by coughing or tapping the handset if you can. If prompted, press 55- this lets the Police call operator know it's a genuine emergency and you'll be put through to the Police swiftly.
